topic.title: ZeroStore ZeroCart ZeroMarket Shopping Carts on ZeroNet
topic.body:
Hi, I dreamt up some ideas for how to have a store on ZeroNet, somewhat in line with ZenCart but "simpler". 

The orders can be public-key encrypted, so even though everyone is sharing them in the database, only the seller can see what they are.  

The payment method can be through any cryptocurrency. The site can be preloaded with addresses, so that each order gets it's own address, and that way can more easily track who paid for their order -- alternatively the sending address would have to be provided by whoever is requesting the product or service.  Could probably even accept paypal, though I wouldn't recommend credit card, since the details would be shared by everyone, even if encrypted. 

The seller can be notified of new purchases by having a bot on their zeronet instance checking for them, and then sending an email once it detects a new order. 

One of the issues would be with obsolete stores, or those which are no longer maintained.  One way to mitigate that would be for the buyer to wait for a confirmation email from the seller before paying. 
I don't know if zeromail has bot handles, but if it does then that could be a possible alternative.

Another option would be to have a ZeroMarket place with multi-signature transactions.  So could have the same level of buyer/seller protection as Paypal.  For example a buyer makes an order, and puts it into a buyer-seller escrow, the seller then ships the item,  once the item has arrived in good working order, then the buyer finishes the transaction and-or writes a review,  if there is some problem the marketplace admins can either refund or give funds as appropriate.

topic.title: How to load json with javascript in zeronet?
topic.body:
I'm making a new search engine. trying to use xmhttprequest to load file and it says.

"Cross-Origin Request Blocked: The Same Origin Policy disallows reading the remote resource at http://127.0.0.1:43111/1SearchPd3khzLtsxTxKYhYUohk7c1QYd/knowledge/0list.json. (Reason: CORS header ‘Access-Control-Allow-Origin’ missing)."

So how do i access other files?

topic.title: Monetizing ZeroNet (Making money from ZeroNet)
topic.body:
I see two ways of making monetizing ZeroNet. 

1. ZeroNet VPN

The first is something many people could do.   We've had some free clearnet portals of ZeroNet in the past, but likely due to the high level of traffic they weren't able to cope and closed down.  One possibility is to make a portal with a ZeroNet portal with a paywall through a VPN, possibly over the tor network.  This would be particularly useful for mobile devices, and for people that don't want to be storing and sharing the content which they visit.

For providers of this service, the main thing to think about, is where to store such servers. It would have to be either countries which don't mind the content on them, or have sufficiently strict privacy laws that they wont check whats on them.   Of course in any case it will be best to encrypt the ZeroNet partition, and it would need a large amount of space. 
If using the tor network for the VPN, then the physical location of the server shouldn't matter too much, so long as there are proper encryption mechanisms in place. 

2.  ZeroNet Coin

The second method is a little bit more involved, and would probably require co-operation of @nofish.  The purpose of the ZeroNet coin, could be avoid certain forms of DDNS which ZeroNet may still be prone to, such as if there was a botnet of modified ZeroNet clients, which only pulled content, and did not share it -- which could if there were enough of them, overload certain websites and make them hard to access for normal users. 

That form of DDNS could be circumvented by serving people that make donations with ZeroNet coin first.  Much like GridCoin, ZeroNet coin could be a reward for contributing bandwidth and storage to the network (for free). The clients would have to be modified so that they would keep track of who gave them how many kiB at what average speed (maybe even what sites). Then some kind of trusted peer consensus would have to be reached, to avoid clients pretending they got stuff to game the system. Several trusted peers can check if they get similar results from that host over a period of time (to also gauge uptime).  
There can probably some process of how a peer goes to become a trusted peer, based on having results like the other trusted peers for a certain period of time. 

Anyways, that's just an idea, would have to be fleshed out by some people more familiar with modern cryptocurrencies.

topic.title: ZeroNet Archive
topic.body:
One thing I've noticed with ZeroNet is there is very little content.  After downloading all the zites I could get a hold of for my filling my search engine,  the sum total is 3.1GB, and there are 1858 zites. 
One way I was thinking that can increase the amount of relevant content, and increase the value of ZeroNet, is to make it similar to archive.org.

Can read more at my blog:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1BLogoyFMSLpVbdJUThDkDui6bEESrbTmW/?Post:3:New+blog+post

1_1LE1ngFyG62KJC1Q7G2xyZGjaB2QubXSi9.body:
If you have BTRFS, can use snapper, then you will always have backups of all your stuff, including whatever the messages are on this site.  Simply can roll back to the latest version that had all the files/messages intact. 
Then can seed a new forum with it. 
If the .bit domain is Not compromised, then can simply flow over to the new one by changing the zeronet: entry,
If the .bit domain is compromised, then will need to use a different one.

3_1A3XsuLB6P7LQPCw1QWASG7RGSwrCv6Xib.body:
@kaffie, I completely agree with you in terms that it should be optional.  It works just fine without cryptocurrency.  
Similar to BOINC, it works just fine without a cryptocurrency, but for those people that are interested, they can be rewarded Gridcoin for contributing to BOINC. 
So for instance vanilla ZeroNet could be sans cryptocurrency, but could have a version that has support for it also. 

I'm not really sure how a 51% attack would work, if you could explain that to me, would be great. Thanks

> [kaffie](#comment_375_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): If you own 51% of the mining power of a blockchain, you can control what happens. It's a huge problem for bitcoin and other large cryptocurrencies that have become centralized as difficulty rose. For smaller currencies it becomes an easy target, depending on the number of nodes. [...]

"Gridcoin has eliminated the possibility of a 51% attack, an attack on a standard Proof-of-Work coin, which involves a single entity owning a minimum of 51% of the total network hash rate. To attack Gridcoin in a similar way, the attacker would have to make a 51% buy-out, meaning he needs to own 51% of all the coins. In addition to the 51%, the attacker would have to buy and hold the cumulative stake weight of all nodes with fewer than 30 blocks staked. Since interest is being payed to those who let their nodes run for the network, transaction fees are not needed in theory. However they are still enforced to prevent transaction spam on a single node.

"These improvements were already made by Blackcoin, which Gridcoin, in an effort to keep up with current technology has implemented. Blackcoin also included the [Zerocash] protocol, a process enabling anonymous transactions."


> Personally, I think if ZeroNet was going to add a cryptocurrency, why not just include a basic bitcoin wallet, or namecoin wallet? All the core dev-work is there, it's massively popular and watched like a hawk, and it'd fit right in with zeronet addresses/users by default. 

Well Namecoin addresses start with an N, so they are different than the Bitcoin addresses used by ZeroNet. 
Also Bitcoin transactions fees are so high that it doesn't make sense for micro-transactions, the transaction fee for bitcoin was about 1 NMC last time I checked, much higher than even bank e-transfers. 

Also the whole point of having a ZeroNet cryptocurrency is to reward people for seeding ZeroNet. It would be impossible to do with a foreign currency as we would actually have to buy that currency, in order to use it to reward people. 

Though a modification of gridcoin could work, where instead of having work-units for helping science, it would be work-units of serving clients.

"Gridcoin features Proof-of-Research (POR) algorithm, in partnership with Berkeley Open Infrastructure for Network Computing,[3] commonly known as BOINC (pronounced /bɔɪŋk/ - rhymes with "oink"). This protocol rewards users of the network once they have completed the computational work unit (WU) in BOINC by linking their Cross-Project ID (CPID) to their Gridcoin wallet. The reward for computation is a proportional payment of Gridcoin (GRC) based on calculations involving the user's recent average credit (RAC)."

"Gridcoin is created daily from two activities, Proof-of-Stake and Proof-of-Research. Proof of Research is produced at a targeted rate of about 50,000 coins per 1000 blocks. A factor is used to adjust rewards to achieve this target and is called a Magnitude Unit and is stored in the blockchain. If the number of coins generated is too low the Magnitude Unit increases, this increases the number of coins paid for a certain magnitude, if the number of coins generated is too high the Magnitude Unit decreases, this decreases the number of coins paid for a certain magnitude. This has the effect of balancing Proof-of-Research payments with Proof-of-Stake payments. Effectively, if fewer researchers are helping to secure the network, the incentive is increased. "

> With a ZN-specific coin, nofish's time and effort would be even more divided than it already is.

Yes, I agree it would make most sense if someone familiar with GridCoin development or at least cryptocurrency development was to spearhead that.   It can be completely or partially independent of ZeroNet main branch. 

If there was a selective clear-net passthrough, (where only particular websites are served to the clearnet),  then ZeroNet could get paid for hosting certain large/commercial clearnet websites,  the coin software would then distribute the coin based on who served what. 
Of course there would have to be a whole extra layer for verification, such as the web clients sending the serving a main server the hash of the site they received, to make sure they got the whole thing. 

This would make ZeroNet kind of like the ultimate cloud hosting solution.

> So there's certainly more than that. Zirch claims over 2,000 sites, but I haven't audited it. So perhaps there really are just 971 unique sites listed.

All the zites on Zirch have been verified and contain content.json's, though not all of them have an index.html.
So for instance of the 2399 currently in zirch index, 61 don't have index.html files. 

It is possible that @freedonn was not waiting long enough in their script, since the search results are returned as they are found, perhaps in the second or so it took his script to run, it only managed to load 900 something results.

Another anomaly I noticed, is that some zites are not accessible in tor-only mode, so I had to setup a clearnet one to get those which weren't in the tor network for whatever reason.

> [butts](#comment_2_1EnBwsMpLpryB15vaFSixFPHDpfot7nRaj): is gray alien the name of a particular species or is that just a color?

It is more of a genus or family, genetically speaking they are too diverse to be considered a single species.  Basically they specialize in genetic engineering and live underground.  So various "models" of Grays are made for different purposes,  and each hive has it's own mix, because they harvest their own genetic material for making amendments to newer versions of various host bodies. 

The Grays as a collective are sometimes referred to as the "Orion Group".  There is also the Draconian Empire (mostly reptilians), and the Galactic Federation (mostly mammals).  The Orion Group is full of various hybrids.

1_1MEWJRMLgvofqG9Mbsb2Rc4hFFyv7HeRx7.body:
if there were millions of users, there would be multiple kinds of clients, and a lot more proxies. including pay proxies.
for instance there could be clients that only choose to store frequently visited websites, or recently visited ones.
and clients that don't share, or have sharing quotas.

Clients could have a "privacy mode" where zites are loaded into tmpfs (RAM), and deleted after the client closes or a shutdown occurs, destroying all evidence of ever having visited.

Yes, I've done it.
First create a new zite,
Use httrack to download the zite. 
Set the "size_limit":  to be larger in megabytes than the current size of you site,
in for your zite in the data/sites.json file 
then it will sign properly

But yeah, if you could do it by wiki subtopics, and have each under 10MB, this would be ideal. as some people and proxies don't automatically increase the size past 10MB

2_1BiouZaoK2zKaqSihxi7LudLqix6ynXYtj.body:
The NSA can see everything you are doing on your computer via the Clipper Chip in your CPU, either ARM's TrustZone, Intel's ME, or AMD's PSP.   Unless you have one of the old chips that don't have clipper chips, like the AMD Opteron
or something else RYF certified. https://www.fsf.org/resources/hw/endorsement/respects-your-freedom

In the future RISC-V may be the only option if you don't want a clipper chip integrated in your computer. Though at present the HiFive  Arduino board is the only available RISC-V SoC, and it only has 16kB of RAM, (not enough for linux).

> [cosmologica](#comment_59_1PiXrhT1UjMZmJc5WFhfUxourdfapeHJ8o): Maybe in the future old PC's equal their weight in gold.

Problem is that the half-life of most computing components is between 4 and 7 years. 
So for hard-drives it's around 5, and for CPU's it's about 7.  
Interlagos Opteron's were released in 2011, so about 50% of first production will be defunct in 2018.
last production of Opteron was in 2016, (though not sure that included Interlagos), so that should be enough to get through till 2023.  Hopefully by then RISC-V will have commercially available server and end-user chips available.

I know some people that try to keep 15 year old computers alive, and it is just endless toil with the soldering gun and spare parts. at the 14 yr mark only 25% of original production is still operational -- so three out of four spare parts are recycling.

2_1GmJVE6KmMyRKKfEg2aiTjCtCU5poP3Rde.body:
> [obiwanzanobi](#comment_39_1LUy9iAxeWsj1DP5L8V17Yb2vo87FucjgD): then explain to me why the example link below gives me the Site:1FqhRo..4N4w Content.json not exist: data/1FqhRosMouo37Z8iDpLTEPvfznBq1b4N4w/content.jsonerror?

content not found json error is fairly common, just means your zeronet server hasn't found enough peers, or peers that have it.  usually can wait a few hours and it'll be found.  unless the original person didn't seed it to enough people.

> [vajag88](#comment_6_1P9VFgUn4ov1WCAy3xhSWHCiFR9hjSwdrT): Before muslims, human bombs started indian buddhist - explode Ghandi and Neru families. 

That's false, Tamil people are primarily Hindu, 
and there is no evidence either way what religion the Tamil faction was.
The Tamil Tigers for instance that caused a lot of terrorism in Sri Lanka, 
were Hindu, however the organization considered itself Atheist. 

I have to admit though, that Theraveda Buddhism is somewhat "extremist", in that it doesn't accept other religions. Whereas Mahayana (and Vajrayana) accepts the mixing of faiths -- which is why shinto-buddhism, daoist-buddhism and even tantric buddhism (tantra was adopted from hinduism) can exist.   

So the Tamil Tigers may have felt left out because they were Hindu, and decided to try to kill all the Buddhists in Sri Lanka.  It may have been different if Sri Lanka had Mahayana Buddhism, as they could have instead become Hindu-Buddhists and thus felt included.  

> Japanese kamikadze - buddhist-sintoist.

9_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof.body:
How about Pyash?
Though admittedly it's software is not ready yet, 
it is a language designed for machine translation, 
and for compute programming.  

So (once the software is ready) statements you make in Pyash will be available in hundreds of languages with similar precision as programming languages. 
One of the best parts is you don't have to learn the Pyash words, simply the subset of your native language which is supported. 
 

Currently there is an alpha version of the chat available.
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1hc6tqoeAQ6B9bacSSs1uo2YN6W75Vy1a
Also in the works is an evolutionary programmer
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1vLoKesxKQDnLFrmJDoUXyrWX1h2YwSGJ/prom/2017/09/12/Evolutionary-Programmer-Training-Teaching-Two.html
